newsitem.title: UK: Russia issues first international bond since 1917.
newsitem.headline: Russia issues first international bond since 1917.

text.p: Russia launched a larger-than-expected $1.0 billion five-year Eurobond Thursday, the country's first international bond offering since the 1917 revolution.
The offering will pave the way for other Russian borrowers to follow, such as the cities of Moscow, St Petersburg and the Sverdlovsk region.
Companies like Russia's RAO Gazprom, the world's largest natural gas producer, Russia's biggest oil group NK LUKoil and the Russian Railways Ministry are also likely to follow suit.

The Eurobond, which had been discussed for some two years, is expected to yield 3.45 percentage points more than five-year U.S. Treasury notes, which currently have a rate of 5.91 percent, joint lead managers J.P. Morgan and SBC Warburg said.

While the yield was in line with market expectations, the size of the Eurobond was a surprise. Originally, the market had expected up to $500 million. As recently as Wednesday, bankers were talking about a $750 million issue.
The increases followed a promotional extravaganza in which three teams of Russian bankers and advisers toured 14 cities in less than two weeks.
Investors and bankers flocked to a presentation in London last Friday where Russia's Finance Minister Alexander Livshits said he wanted the Eurobond to show the country was a respectable borrower.
The marketing campaign started in Tokyo and culminated in New York Wednesday.

A number of hurdles needed to be overcome before the issue could be launched. These included the Russian presidential elections mid-year, credit ratings from the key rating agencies and President Boris Yeltsin's recovery from recent heart surgery.
Yeltsin said he was in a "fighting mood" on Wednesday.
Also on Wednesday Russian officials released some MinFin domestic bonds which had been frozen.
Russia is rated Ba2 by Moody's Investors Service and BB-minus by Standard & Poor's Corp., which are below investment grade but were at the top end of market expectations when assigned in October.
